evidence0.title: Neo-Nazi | Southern Poverty Law Center
evidence0.snippet: After several years of struggling to hold mass in-person events, the neo-Nazi movement managed to regain some of its organizational footing in 2023.
evidence0.htmlSnippet: After several years of struggling to hold mass in-person events, the neo-Nazi movement managed to regain some of its organizational footing in 2023.

metatags.twitter:title: Neo-Nazi
metatags.og:title: Neo-Nazi
metatags.og:description: Neo-Nazi groups share a hatred for Jews and a love for Adolf Hitler and Nazi Germany. While they also hate nonwhite people, LGBTQ people and even sometimes Christians, they perceive “the Jew” as their cardinal enemy.
metatags.twitter:creator: @splcenter
metatags.twitter:description: Neo-Nazi groups share a hatred for Jews and a love for Adolf Hitler and Nazi Germany. While they also hate nonwhite people, LGBTQ people and even sometimes Christians, they perceive “the Jew” as

website_content.content:
Top Takeaways
-------------
After several years of struggling to hold mass in-person events, the neo-Nazi movement managed to regain some of its organizational footing in 2023. On Sept. 2, more than 50 members of Blood Tribe, Goyim Defense League, Vinland Rebels and other white power activists gathered in Orlando, Florida, for the “March of the Red Shirts,” marking  neo-Nazi demonstrations since the flurry of white power movement activity between 2016 and 2018. The same day, about a dozen white power activists with the Florida-based Order of the Black Sun staged their own rally outside of Walt Disney World in Orlando, where white power activists shouted various slurs, waved Nazi flags and destroyed an LGBTQ+ Pride flag.
Though the March of the Red Shirts brought an unprecedented number of neo-Nazi activists together for the first time in several years, it followed on the heels of similar, albeit smaller, flash demonstrations organized by neo-Nazi activists in Ohio, Texas, Wisconsin, Florida, Massachusetts, Maine and Tennessee. These events are seldom advertised in advance and rarely attract more than one to two dozen activists. Nevertheless, they show a growing willingness among white power organizers to risk arrest, conflict with antifascist and antiracist demonstrators, or face other legal quagmires.
As the movement has shifted its focus back toward in-person organizing, neo-Nazi activists have elected to devote...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The SPLC is a highly regarded organization that monitors hate groups, domestic extremism, and civil rights violations. It has a long history of documenting and analyzing extremist movements and provides research backed by comprehensive data. While sometimes criticized for bias, particularly in its labeling of groups, its track record for accuracy and thorough reporting in understanding hate and extremism is strong. It is a valuable resource for identifying neo-Nazi activities and extremist gatherings.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence discusses the resurgence of neo-Nazi gatherings and specific events that underline their agenda and organization. It mentions significant group names and actions that reflect their ideology and gathering structure, which directly relates to understanding the agenda of the group depicted in the video.

Few details have emerged about Portland's response to a rally of neo-Nazi members that erupted in violence on city hall steps back...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: Maine Public is a nonprofit news service providing local and national news. It has established credibility as a news source; however, its focus is primarily regional, which may limit the depth of reporting on national extremist events. Overall, it maintains journalistic standards, though it may not specialize in combatting fake news specifically.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence references a demonstration by neo-Nazis that resulted in violence, hinting at the aggressive actions typical of neo-Nazi ideology. It indicates that there are in-person events linked with neo-Nazi actions; however, it does not provide specific details about the agenda or speaker rhetoric at those events.

metatags.citation_title: The Escalating Terrorism Problem in the United States
metatags.twitter:title: The Escalating Terrorism Problem in the United States | CSIS
metatags.og:title: The Escalating Terrorism Problem in the United States
metatags.og:description: The United States faces a growing terrorism problem that will likely worsen in the next year, particularly around the 2020 presidential election. The most significant threat likely comes from white supremacists, though anarchists and religious extremists could also pose a threat.
metatags.twitter:description: The United States faces a growing terrorism problem that will likely worsen in the next year, particularly around the 2020 presidential election. The most significant threat likely comes from white supremacists, though anarchists and religious extremists could also pose a threat.

website_content.content:
#### **THE ISSUE**
_The United States faces a growing terrorism problem that will likely worsen over the next year. Based on a CSIS data set of terrorist incidents, the most significant threat likely comes from white supremacists, though anarchists and religious extremists inspired by the Islamic State and al-Qaeda could present a potential threat as well. Over the rest of 2020, the terrorist threat in the United States will likely rise based on several factors, including the November 2020 presidential election._
* * *
On June 3, 2020, federal authorities arrested three individuals allegedly associated with the “boogaloo” movement, a loosely-organized group of extremists preparing for a civil war, for conspiring to cause violence in Las Vegas and possessing an improvised incendiary device.1 Less than a week later, law enforcement officials near Richmond, VA, arrested Harry H. Rogers, a member of the Ku Klux Klan, for driving a vehicle into peaceful protesters. Around the same time, members of a Brooklyn anarchist group urged its supporters to conduct “rebellion” against the government.2 Extremists from all sides flooded social media with disinformation, conspiracy theories, and incitements to violence in response to the protests following the death of George Floyd, swamping Twitter, YouTube, Facebook, and other platforms.3
This CSIS brief examines the state of terrorism in the United States. It asks two sets of questions. First, what are the most significant types of terrorism in the United States, and how has the terrorism threat in the U.S. homeland evolved over time...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: CSIS is a reputable think tank known for its in-depth research and analysis on national security, including issues pertaining to extremism and terrorism. The reports and publications produced by CSIS usually come from well-respected experts in their fields. Thus, while it may not be a dedicated fake news detector, its analytical rigor supports accurate information.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: While this source discusses the threat posed by white supremacists, it lacks specific information about individual gatherings or their agendas. It does not provide direct insight into the speakers or the context of their ideology as it pertains to a singular event in 2023.

evidence3.title: The US National Strategy to Counter Antisemitism | The White House
evidence3.htmlTitle: The US National Strategy to Counter Antisemitism | The White House
evidence3.snippet: MAY 2023. Page 2. May 25, 2023. Six years ago, Neo-Nazis marched from the shadows through Charlottesville, Virginia, chanting,. “Jews will not replace us.
evidence3.htmlSnippet: MAY 2023. Page 2. May 25, 2023. Six years ago, Neo-Nazis marched from the shadows through Charlottesville, Virginia, chanting,. “Jews will not replace us.

website_content.content:
T H E U . S . N A T I O N A L S T R A T E G Y T O C O U N T E R A N T I S E M I T I S M 1
# THE U.S. NATIONAL 
# STRATEGY TO COUNTER 
# ANTISEMITISM 
# MAY 2023 May 25, 2023 
Six years ago, Neo -Nazis marched from the shadows through Charlottesville, Virginia, chanting, 
“Jews will not replace us.” With torches in hand, they spewed the same antisemitic bile and hate 
that were heard across Europe in the 1930s. What happened in Charlottesville —the horror of that 
moment, the violence that followed, and the threat it represented for American democracy —
drove me to run for President. The very soul of our Nation was hanging in the balance. It still is 
today. 
Repeated episodes of hate —including numerous attack s on Jewish Americans —have since 
followed Charlottesville, shaking our moral conscience as Americans and challenging the values 
for which we stand as a Nation. That is why I convened the first -ever United We Stand Summit 
at the White House in September 2022 : to bring communities from across the country together to 
combat hate in all its forms —including the persistent scourge of antisemitism —that has long 
plagued our Nation. We must stand united —regardless of our backgrounds and beliefs —to 
affir m that an attack on any one group of us is an attack on us all and that hate can have no safe 
harbor in America. 
Together, we must...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The official website of the U.S. government provides verified information directly from governmental sources, making it a reliable source for facts and updates regarding policies or statements made. However, as a government entity, it may present information in a manner aligned with current administration viewpoints, which can introduce a bias, especially in politically charged contexts.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This document addresses the historical context of neo-Nazi actions and the broader implications of antisemitism in the U.S. Although it sets up a background for neo-Nazi activities, it does not provide details on current gatherings, agendas, or speakers that would connect directly to the specified video.

Robert Wirch, Wisconsin State Senator, District 22
===============   
]

!
Welcome to my updated website! In order to provide you with the latest information and best constituent services, I have made several changes. I hope that you will find everything you are looking for.
I am honored to represent you in the Wisconsin State Senate, and I take that responsibility very seriously. Following the 2011 legislative redistricting, the 22nd Senate District includes the city of Kenosha, most of the city of Racine, and parts of Somers, Mount Pleasant, and Elmwood Park. I was born and raised in the area; I raised my children here. As a result, I believe that service to you, my friends and neighbors, is the most important part of my job.
In addition to good constituent services, there are a number of issues that are near and dear to me. Things like mental health coverage, workers’ rights, quality education, economic development and improved access to health care are issues that I have fought for during my time in the Legislature. These are issues that impact all of us. In order to do my job, I rely on your input on legislative matters, so when you have thoughts or concerns about where the state is headed, share them with me. I want to know what you think.
Thank you for visiting my website and for allowing me to serve as your State Senator. I look forward to hearing from...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: This site is the official legislative site for the Wisconsin government, offering public access to recent legislation, statutes, and governmental activities. It holds reliability as a primary source of legal and legislative information, crucial for understanding state matters. It may not focus on news detection, but the accuracy of legislative processes enhances its credibility.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This source contains general information about the political figure's efforts and service, with no specific information related to neo-Nazi ideology or gathering agendas. It does not adequately address the question at hand regarding the ideology of the groups depicted in the video.

website_content.content:
_, The Texas Tribune’s daily newsletter that keeps readers up to speed on the most essential Texas news._
* * *
Texas continues to be a hotbed for extremism and antisemitism, driven by the heavy presence of white supremacist and anti-LGBTQ+ groups that are headquartered or active in the state.
That’s according to a report released Thursday by the Anti-Defamation League that examined nearly three years of “alarming levels of extremist ideology and activity” in Texas, and suggested a handful of policies to combat the growing problem.
Since 2021, the report found,  in the state have jumped by 89%, and there have been six “terrorist plots” in addition to 28 “extremist events” such as training and rallies. Texas also led the nation in  last year; had the  charged in relation to the Jan. 6, 2021 insurrection; and, in March, saw a  kill 8 people at an Allen shopping mall.
The report specifically noted the presence of white supremacist groups such as Patriot Front, which is based in the Dallas area and has repeatedly marched in major cities across the country, including this . Patriot Front was founded by Texas resident Thomas Rousseau after 2017’s deadly neo-Nazi march in Charlottesville, Virginia, and was responsible for roughly 80% of all  incidents nationwide last year. The group also was present at former President Donald Trump’s  this year, and 31 of its members were arrested near a 2022 Idaho Pride event on 
The AD...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The Texas Tribune is a nonprofit news organization that provides comprehensive coverage of Texas politics and policy. It is well-respected for its investigative journalism and commitment to transparency and accuracy. Its focus on state-level reporting allows for high-quality coverage but might not extensively cover national extremist activities outside Texas.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence outlines the rise of extremist activity and mentions the presence of specific white supremacist groups. It indicates a trend in Texas that could relate to gatherings similar to the one depicted in the video but lacks specific details about the agenda or content of speeches at such gatherings.

1.  
NCJRS Virtual Library
=====================
The Virtual Library houses over 235,000 criminal justice resources, including all known OJP works.
Skinhead International: A Worldwide Survey of Neo-Nazi Skinheads
================================================================
NCJ Number
171471
Date Published
1995
Length
89 pages
Annotation
This study provides information on neo-Nazi Skinhead white supremacist groups in the 33 countries where they are active, including their numbers and activities.
Abstract
Data sources for this 18-month global study included Jewish communal institutions, human rights organizations, law enforcement agencies, university-based research centers, defectors, and confidential sources. Reasonable estimates on the numbers of Skinheads in each country were obtained by tallying Skinhead numbers at rallies, marches, concerts, festivals, soccer matches, and other gatherings. The Skinhead movement is active in 33 countries on six continents. It numbers some 70,000 youths worldwide, of whom half are hardcore activists and the rest supporters. The countries where Skinheads are found in the greatest numbers are Germany (5,000), Hungary and the Czech Republic (more than 4,000 each), the United States (3,500), Poland (2,000), the United Kingdom and Brazil (1,500 each), Italy (1,000 to 1,500), and Sweden (more than 1,000). France, Spain, Canada, and the Netherlands each have at least 500 Skinheads. The Skinhead movements in these various countries are extensively linked with each other. This "Skinhead International" is maintained through the travels abroad of popular Skinhead rock bands and their fans; the worldwide marketing of Skinhead paraphernalia and recordings; the sale and trading of publications; the exchange of propaganda; and the use of electronic communications. In all the countries where they exist Skinheads engage in violence and criminal assaults on racial minorities, immigrants...[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: The OJP is a government agency that administers federal justice grants and research. It is a credible source for crime statistics and analysis; however, it is primarily focused on justice-related programs rather than explicit news reporting. While the data it provides is reliable, it may not directly address fake news detection.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This study provides background on neo-Nazi skinheads and their presence worldwide but does not focus on specific gatherings or their agendas in 2023. It does less to connect directly to the video or to the specifics of their ideologies compared to other sources.

metatags.twitter:title: State officials to visit Quincy 3 days after neo-Nazis march outside ENC migrant shelter
metatags.og:title: State officials to visit Quincy 3 days after neo-Nazis march outside ENC migrant shelter
metatags.og:description: Officials from various state agencies, together with college representatives, will present details of the program and answer questions.
metatags.twitter:creator: @patriotledger
metatags.article:author: Peter Blandino
metatags.twitter:description: Officials from various state agencies, together with college representatives, will present details of the program and answer questions.

website_content.content:
QUINCY − At the request of Quincy officials, state authorities will talk about a shelter for  at a community meeting Tuesday, Sept. 12, at 6:30 p.m. at Central Middle School.
Read what happened at the meeting 
The meeting will be held three days after a group calling itself NSC-131 held a demonstration outside a dormitory housing migrant families at the college.
Quincy police said that at about 8:30 p.m. Saturday, 25 to 30 white men in khakis and face masks marched to the site housing the families and "stood on a public sidewalk while holding flares, a banner and chanting for the migrant families to 'go home' and that they 'were not welcome.'"
The group left after 15 to 20 minutes, police said. No vandalism or violence was reported.
The same group held a similar demonstration  to protest the state's placement of homeless people there, including Haitians fleeing the violence and poverty in their home country.
According to the  is a neo-Nazi group based in New England. NSC is an abbreviation for National Socialist Club. The German Nazi Party was officially called the National Socialist German Workers Party.
NSC-131 originated in Massachusetts in December 2019, particularly in Worcester, Boston, Quincy, Rutland and Sturbridge, according to the Anti-Defamation League.
!
On Sunday, a group of Quincy residents visited the campus with multilingual welcome signs and cutouts of hearts. In a , organizer Maggie McKee thanked those who attended the counterprotest.
"If you...[Content truncated]

It provides reliable local reporting, but it may not have the resources or specialized focus on national issues of extremism or fake news detection. Like many local outlets, it can provide accurate reporting but lacks the broader analytical depth found in national sources.

metatags.twitter:title: Neo-Nazis marched in Madison on Saturday. Here’s what happened — and what didn’t.
metatags.og:title: Neo-Nazis marched in Madison on Saturday. Here’s what happened — and what didn’t.
metatags.og:description: Neo-Nazis tied to the group Blood Tribe waved swastika flags and chanted antisemitic rhetoric in downtown Madison outside the Wisconsin Capitol.
metatags.twitter:creator: @journalsentinel
metatags.article:author: Tyler Katzenberger
metatags.twitter:description: Neo-Nazis tied to the group Blood Tribe waved swastika flags and chanted antisemitic rhetoric in downtown Madison outside the Wisconsin Capitol.

website_content.content:
[Content truncated]..., according to the . The group "openly directs its vitriol at Jews, 'non-whites' and the LGBTQ+ community.”
The group led demonstrations nationwide in 2023, including a hateful protest at a July  event in Watertown. Neo-Nazis brandished rifles, displayed swastikas and hurled homophobic slurs and threats at LGBTQ+ people during the event.
!
I saw social media posts saying the group was affiliated with Antifa. Is that true?
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
No. There is currently no evidence to support claims the neo-Nazi group was associated with left-wing anti-fascist group Antifa, as some social media replies suggested.
This is a common falsehood used to divert blame at events led by white supremacists and right-wing extremists, including the Jan. 6, 2021,  at the U.S. Capitol.
Additionally, there is no available evidence the group consisted of federal agents, or “the feds,” as some users claimed on social media.
**Who led Saturday’s demonstration?**
-------------------------------------
Christopher Pohlhaus, nicknamed “Hammer,” is the Blood Tribe’s leader and a former U.S. Marine. Pohlhaus was one of two unmasked figures at Saturday’s neo-Nazi march.
Pohlhaus, originally from Texas, founded the group in 2021, according to the . He was present at other Blood Tribe neo-Nazi events in 2023.
In 2022, Pohlhaus purchased 10 acres of land in Maine to construct a white supremacist encampment. The  reported Pohlhaus sold the land in October due to public pressure, but Pohlhaus said he owned larger plots elsewhere in the state.
!
Were the demonstrators from Madison?
------------------------------------
It’s impossible to say for sure, but available evidence suggests the group came from outside the city.
Pictures posted to  showed the group leaving in a U-Haul and SUV after the rally near a park on Madison’s east side. The SUV had a Kentucky license plate.
Pohlhaus, the group’s leader, resided in Maine as of October 2023.
Was the group armed?
--------------------
One member of the group appeared armed with a knife but the others at Saturday's march weren't visibly armed. Group members could have carried concealed weapons.
Members of the Blood Tribe have brandished rifles at past events, including the July “Pride in the Park” event in Watertown.
Why didn’t the police stop the neo-Nazis?
-----------------------------------------
The neo-Nazi group...[Content truncated]

Its coverage may lack the national emphasis required to engage deeply with freedom of speech or hate group issues extensively.

metatags.twitter:title: Biden uses Charlottesville to talk about political violence. But he hasn't been there
metatags.og:title: Biden uses Charlottesville to talk about political violence. But he hasn't been there
metatags.og:description: President Biden says the 2017 Nazi rally in Charlottesville, Va., was a critical moment for the country, and pushed him to run for president against Trump.
metatags.cxenseparse:author: Deepa Shivaram

website_content.content:
!
The street where Heather Heyer was killed during the Nazi rally in 2017 has been renamed to Heather Heyer Way. Residents in Charlottesville say that day still leaves an impact on the town. **Deepa Shivaram/NPR** ****hide caption****
****toggle caption****
Deepa Shivaram/NPR
  !
The street where Heather Heyer was killed during the Nazi rally in 2017 has been renamed to Heather Heyer Way. Residents in Charlottesville say that day still leaves an impact on the town.
Deepa Shivaram/NPR
It's been more than six years since images of a neo-Nazi rally in Charlottesville, Va., shocked the world — hundreds of people with tiki torches chanted antisemitic slurs, and a counter-protester, Heather Heyer, was killed.
The events of Aug. 12, 2017, were so shocking that they motivated Joe Biden, who had mostly retired from political life, to run for president against Donald Trump. He said hearing Trump saying there were "very fine people on both sides" that day in Charlottesville was a defining moment.
"In that moment, I knew the threat to this nation was unlike any I had ever seen in my lifetime," Biden says in his 2019 video announcing his run for president.
But as much as Biden talks about Charlottesville, some residents are wondering why he hasn't visited the town.
### What it would mean for Biden to visit
"If that made an impact on him ... he said that was one of the reasons he ran, then why wouldn't you? I mean that would be something you do," Carla Hunt, a former educator, said.
Student Amy Little said Biden should "absolutely" visit.
"I think there's a certain gravity in coming and seeing where those things happen and really kind of getting a sense and breathing the air and seeing the sites," she said.
  !
Amy Little (left), a student and longtime resident in Charlottesville, said Biden should "absolutely" come visit the town. **Deepa Shivaram/NPR** ****hide caption****
****toggle caption****
Deepa Shivaram/NPR
  !
Amy Little (left), a student and longtime resident in Charlottesville, said Biden should "absolutely" come visit the town.
Deepa Shivaram/NPR
Others said a visit from Biden wouldn't make much of a difference.
"2017 was a long time ago now. There's a pandemic, there's a whole bunch of other places that have happened since then....[Content truncated]

website_quality_evaluation.justification: NPR is widely recognized for its in-depth reporting and commitment to fact-based journalism. It has established a strong reputation for balancing viewpoints while providing accurate context and analysis on various issues, including extremism. Its editorial standards and fact-checking processes enhance its role as an effective resource for identifying misinformation.

Relevance.Relevance Justification: This evidence primarily discusses the lasting impact of a historic event (Charlottesville) and does not pertain to the current agenda or speakers at recent neo-Nazi gatherings. Although it reflects on the implications of neo-Nazi ideologies, it does not provide direct insights needed to address the current question.
